Dear Ms. Harding:
Attached is the Interim Report for the above referenced facility completed on February 1,
2022. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, sections of the contract and
Modified Settlement Agreement (MISEP) requirements, a written corrective action plan is
required. It should be noted that violations of any licensing rules are also violations of the
MISEP and your contract. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this
letter and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or MISEP citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager, Jessica VandenHeuvel, at (616) 204-
6992.

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except
for the following:
R 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy
(1) Agency’s medical and dental care policy shall, at a minimum,
include all of the following:
(c) A physical examination for each child as follows, unless a
greater frequency is medically indicated:
(II) For a child 2 years of age or older, a physical examination
shall be completed within 30 calendar days after placement.
One of six open foster care files reviewed did not have an initial medical examination
completed within 30 calendar days after placement as required.
File one: Child was removed on 9/17/2021 and initial medical examination was
completed on 10/18/2021.
R 400.12418 Development of service plans
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for each child
and parent or parents, as follows:
(a) Within 30 calendar days from removal of the home.
One of six open foster care files reviewed did not have the initial service plan
completed within 30 calendar days from removal as required.
File one: Child was removed on 10/8/2021 and Initial Service Plan was completed on
12/8/2021.
R 400.12421 Visitation and parenting time
An agency shall have a policy regarding visitation and parenting
time that contains, at a minimum, all of the following:
(b) An agency social service worker shall visit the foster child
and the foster parent in the foster parent’s home at least once
every month.
4

One of six open foster care files reviewed did not have monthly visitation with the
worker and child in the foster placement as required.
File one: There is no documented home visit with the child in the foster placement for
the month of June 2021.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
1/15/2021 RENEWAL, CAP approved 2/11/2021
3/17/2020 INTERIM, CAP approved 3/25/2020
R 400.12327 Special evaluation
(1) An agency shall do all of the following when anyone in the
agency receives information that relates to possible
noncompliance with any foster home rule:
(a) Submit a special investigation record to the department’s
licensing authority within 5 working days in the manner
prescribed by the department.
One of three special investigations reviewed did not submit a special investigation
record to the department’s licensing authority within 5 working days as required.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
1/15/2021 RENEWAL, CAP approved 2/11/2021
R 400.12327 Special evaluation
(1) An agency shall do all of the following when anyone in the
agency receives information that relates to possible
noncompliance with any foster home rule:
(3) An agency shall complete a special evaluation within 45
calendar days after receipt of the information.
One of three special investigations reviewed were not completed within 45 calendar
days after receipt of the information as required. There was not documentation of an
extension or director approval.
R 400.12212 Personnel records
(3) The personnel record shall contain:
(a) A written evaluation of a staff member’s performance
within a probationary period or not later than 6 months after the
staff member assumes his or her current responsibilities. After
the initial evaluation, a written evaluation shall be conducted
each year.
5

Two of six personnel files reviewed did not contain written evaluations as required.
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an MISEP violation. Please note that
there are additional MISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1.
The facility is in compliance will all additional MISEP requirements.
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a DHS Contract violation. Please note
that there are additional DHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be
included in section 1. The facility is in compliance will all additional DHS
Contract/Policy requirements except for the following:
FOM 801-03 Medical passports
Initial medical passport
For children entering foster care, the initial medical passport must
be provided within two weeks of the child/youth's placement date
to the following:
 Foster care provider.
 Young adult voluntary foster care (YAVFC) youth/young adult
re-entering foster care.
One of six open foster care files reviewed did not have medical passports as required.
File one: Child was removed on 9/17/2021 and the initial medical passport was
provided on 10/6/2021.
FOM 722-08 Supervisor approval
The supervisor must approve all case service plans within 14
days of the end of the report period.
One of six foster care files reviewed did not have supervisory approval of the case
service plan within 14 days as required.

FOM 722-06H Quality visits
Quality visits between the caseworker and child have been
found to produce positive outcomes for children in foster
care. A quality visit is defined as one in which the
caseworker:
 Can meet with each child individually, without the
presence of other individuals, to give the child an
opportunity to ask questions as well as discuss the
current placement.
 Views the child's bedroom and sleeping arrangements.
 Verifies safe sleep environments and practices for infants
under 12 months.
 Assesses each child’s educational, medical, dental,
mental health and other needs and takes appropriate
action or offers services in response to the identified
needs of each child.
 Shows interest in the child to build and establish rapport.
 Shares and explains the case plan, including the plan for
parenting time, visits with siblings and other relatives,
7

and the child's permanency plan, in a developmentally
appropriate way while allowing the child to ask questions
and express viewpoints.
Three of six foster care files reviewed did not contain documentation of a quality visit.
File one: sleep arrangements not verified during 11/19 visit, no documented
interaction with foster parent on 8/16 visit, and 7/9 Social work contact is very short
and not detailed regarding child's progress, needs, etc.
File two: 7/8 home visit does not meet the requirements of a quality visit due to a lack
of detail. 7/20 home visit was partial and lacking detail.
File three: 2/15 home visit does not meet the requirements of a quality visit, 4/23, 5/25
and 9/30 home visits do not document that sleeping arrangements were verified.
FOM 722-08E Foster Care/Juvenile Justice Summary
The caseworker must complete the DHS-69, Foster Care/Juvenile
Justice Action Summary and upload to MISACWIS within the
timeframe required for the specified action/change.
One of six foster care files reviewed did not have the DHS-69 Action Summary forms
completed for placement changes as required.
FOM 722-06H Timely entry of case contacts
The caseworker must enter the required face-to-face
contacts listed below in MISACWIS within five business days
of the contact. This includes attempted and missed face-to-
face contacts.
Five of six foster care files reviewed contained contacts that were not entered within
five business days.
FOM 722-06B FTM Documentation
The DHS-1105, FTM Report, must be completed for every FTM.
The caseworker must enter the FTM information in MiSACWIS
using the FTM hyperlink within seven business days of the FTM.
Four of six foster care files reviewed contained FTM’s without the DHS 1105 or the
DHS 1105 was not uploaded within seven business days.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
1/15/2021 RENEWAL, CAP approved 2/11/2021
8

SRM 200 Fingerprints
Personnel Training
SAT is required to be taken within six months of working in a
position with CW-CHRI access and every two years
thereafter. CPAs are responsible for ensuring that all
personnel with CHRI access completes SAT timely.
Based on review of the SRM 200 spreadsheet, two current employees were found to
be in non-compliance to timely certification of Security Awareness Training (SAT).
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas
 Document on the signature line of PATP’s if mailed, refused, not returned,
etc.
 Ensure staff are reviewing home visit guide so that required components of a
quality visit are covered.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility did not request consultation during this review.
EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There was one incident of substantiated child abuse and/or neglect during this
licensing period. A special evaluation initiated on 2/11/2021 determined the foster
parents did not provide adequate supervision and did not follow an established
safety plan that resulted in a foster child being sexually abused. The foster parents
were substantiated for abuse and neglect and the license was recommended for
revocation. The agency’s findings and recommendation were found to be
appropriate based on the information obtained during the investigation.
There was one incident of substantiated corporal punishment during this
licensing period. A special evaluation initiated on 2/11/2021 determined the foster
parents were tying a foster child to a chair as a form of discipline. The family was
found to be in violation of licensing rules and agency policy. The agency pursued
revocation due to another incident that resulted in the foster parents being
substantiated for abuse and neglect.
The agency has submitted one acceptable corrective action plan not related to
maltreatment during this licensing period in response to the 2021 Renewal
Inspection Report. During this period under review the agency expressed the
impact that the COVID-19 pandemic had on overall compliance. In addition, the
agency noted that staff turnover and retention impacted overall compliance. Four
citations were noted as repeat violations in the current inspection.
9

Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrator Assessment reported the agency’s difficulty in meeting
requirements during this review period. The assessment reported the previous year
CAP was helpful, specifically with licensing. The agency has had some struggles
during this review period due to COVID-19. In addition, the Chief Administrator (CA)
reported the agency has had difficulty hiring and maintaining staff. The assessment
noted a shortage of qualified applicants. The CA indicated that virtual training has
been difficult for new staff. In addition, restrictions due to COVID-19 have been a
barrier to meeting requirements. The CA reports that agency processes will continue
to be updated and reviewed with staff to ensure expectations are clear.
Interviews
Interviews were conducted with three staff via telephone. Staff acknowledged that this
past year has been challenging due to COVID-19 but felt as though the agency had
adapted well during the previous year. Staff reported feeling supported by supervision
and available as needed. Staff did report that staff morale could be better but felt as
though that was not due to the agency and was common at other agencies.
VI. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
There were no identified safety concerns.
VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules and/or MISEP requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon
receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility
continue on a regular license.
